awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SCC: Scoping an NSF Prize Challenge For Smart and Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to design and structure a Smart & Connected Communities (S&CC) Prize Challenge that provides innovative solutions to technically and socially complex needs that are of broad and pressing interest to communities. The proposer will harness the expertise of researchers, communities, philanthropy, and industry to scope and plan the Prize Challenge, including: 1) identification of prize challenge topics ; 2) the structuring and recruitment of a consortium of funding partners from the philanthropic and corporate community; and 3) the development of a governance structure, launch plan, and review process for the prize challenge.

The research component of this project will test the creation of a new framework that will drive truly integrative, community-focused research done in partnership with funders from philanthropy and industry.  This new structure introduces questions about how community-focused research is crafted and how that research integrates into the broader ecosystem of state and local government, public planning, philanthropic programming, industry research and development (R&D) activities, and collaboration across communities. This process will test the impact of more guided research prompts on the quality of responses from researchers and communities.  It will also seek to create funding partnerships that will broaden the research-to-deployment pipeline, thereby enhancing the technical and societal impact of S&CC research.  The project will draw from MetroLab Network's experience working with universities, communities, philanthropies and other civic-focused stakeholders.  The team will work with a range of partners to undertake this project, including subject-matter experts across S&CC topics; it includes partners who have collaboratively developed new approaches to how data and technology are integrated in the policy planning and implementation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The activities supported by this EAGER led to the launch of a new NSF program, called the Civic Innovation Challenge (“CIVIC”), a national research and action competition in the smart and connected communities domain. The EAGER supported 1) the scoping of a competition that would advance science while creating societal and community impacts; 2) the identification of topics for such a competition; 3) engagement of researchers and communities in the design; and 4) engagement of funding partners from the U.S. Department of Energy and U.S. Department of Homeland Security.

The EAGER supported the scoping of a competition that would harness science for impact in communities. The EAGER team drew inspiration from other high-profile competitions, like the DOT Smart Cities Challenge. The resulting structure involved two stages, the first focused on scoping and refining projects and partnerships and the second focused on pilot deployment. During each phase, teams will work together, gather for workshops, and collaborate on their projects. This structure blends collaboration and competition and allows for meaningful progress for all the teams that participate -- including those that do not advance to stage 1 or stage 2. 

In order to identify potential topics for a national competition, the EAGER team launched an Ideas Competition that generated more than 100 submissions from teams of researchers and civic partners from across the country. 25 of the leading teams were invited to the NSF headquarters for an Ideas Festival that grouped teams together and identified common areas of interest and exploration. This process led to a few universal themes that affect communities of diverse sizes and geographies. The topics for the two tracks of CIVIC stemmed from this process, and represent areas ripe for integrative research, research-civic collaboration, pilot deployment, community engagement, and real-world impact. 

The EAGER activities engaged research and civic partners in ways that helped scope the competition and build a constituency of likely proposers. Beyond the topics that were identified, the Ideas Competition and Ideas Festival explored features of a potential competition, like levels of funding or length of time. In addition to the tangible guidance on topic and structure, the mechanisms to engage the community of research and civic partners was an effective way of gauging interest in the concepts being explored with the EAGER and created attention and publicity in advance of the launch of CIVIC. This allowed partnerships to form and strengthen in advance of CIVIC and creates a new model for engaging stakeholders in federal program design.  

Finally, the EAGER supported outreach to potential joint-funders. Several federal agencies and private philanthropies were engaged throughout the design and several participated in the Ideas Competition and Ideas Festival. Ultimately, the EAGER activities led to a partnership between NSF, the U.S. Department of Energy, and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, each of whom provided funds to support CIVIC. 

This EAGER supported a high-risk, high-reward concept that successfully led to the creation of a new, transformative program at NSF that has proven to capture the interests of researchers and civic partners and has formed partnerships between federal agencies with overlapping interests and funding domains. The EAGER was a terrific mechanism to support the initial scoping of this effort, to prove out a concept, and ready it for implementation.
